=== 1986 Riot ===
+
=== 1986 riot ===
January 1, 1986 was not only the beginning of a new year, but also the date of one of the most famous riots in recent history. The West Virginia Penitentiary was then undergoing many changes and problems. Security had become extremely loose in all areas. Since it was a "cons" prison, most of the locks on the cells had been picked and inmates roamed the halls freely. Bad plumbing and insects caused rapid spreading of various diseases. The prison was now holding more than 2,000 men and crowding became an issue once again. Another major contribution to the riot's cause was the fact that it was a holiday. Many of the guards had called off work, which fueled the prisoners to conduct their plan on this specific day.

From 1899 to 1959, ninety-four men were [[Capital punishment|executed]]. [[Hanging]] was the method of execution until 1949 with eighty-five men meeting that fate. The public could attend hangings until June 19, 1931. On that date, Frank Hyer was executed for murdering his wife. However, when the trap door beneath him was opened and his full weight was put onto the noose, he was instantly decapitated. Following this event, attendance at hangings was by invitation only.<ref name="LastPublicHanging">{{cite news | title=Afterlife Sentence| url=http://www.newsobserver.com/105/story/544546-p2.html | accessdate=2008-11-6}}</ref> The last man to face execution by hanging, Bud Peterson from [[Logan County, West Virginia|Logan County]], lies in the prison's cemetery, as his family refused to claim his body.<ref name="TCGA"/> Beginning in 1951, electrocution became the means of execution. Ironically, the [[Old Sparky|electric chair]] used by the prison was originally built by an inmate there, Paul Glenn.<ref name="TCGA"/> Nine men died in the chair until the state outlawed execution entirely in 1965.<ref name="TCGA"/> The original chair is on display in the facility and is a part of the official tour.<ref name="Official"/>

==Tourism and Training==
+
==Tourism and training==
After the prison closed its doors as a state institution, the Moundsville Economic Development Council obtained a twenty-five year lease on the complex. Tours are available for tourists wishing to see the prison. A [[haunted attraction]] is also set up for the [[Halloween]] season titled the "Dungeon of Horrors". The Elizabethtown Festival is held every May to celebrate and remember historic Moundsville. ==In Pop Culture==
+
==In pop culture==
The prison has appeared in various books, movies, and television shows. Moundsville native [[Davis Grubb]] set his 1953 novel ''[[The Night of the Hunter]]'' in Moundsville with the prison having a notable role. This novel was adapted into a film by [[Charles Laughton]] and [[James Agee]]. The film ''[[The Night of the Hunter (film)|The Night of the Hunter]]'' starred [[Robert Mitchum]] and [[Shelley Winters]]. Davis Grubb also set his novel ''Fools' Parade'' (also known as ''Dynamite Man from Glory Jail'') in Moundsville with the penitentiary serving a notable role here too. The novel was adapted into the 1971 film, ''[[Fools' Parade (film)|Fools' Parade]]'', starring [[James Stewart (actor)|James Stewart]], [[Kurt Russell]], and [[George Kennedy]].
